column1: We tested your cognitive processing speed in two different ways. In one test
column2: you had to press a button when a green box with the word "GO" appeared. This was a test of how quickly you can respond to simple changes. In a second test
column3: you had to correctly match pairs of shapes and numbers. This tested your processing speed and short-term memory. Finally
column4: we asked you to identify synonyms of different words. This tested your long-term memory for words. We are interested in how these different types of cognitive processing relate to each other and how they change as we get older.

column1: There are some limitations you should keep in mind as you look at your feedback. Each of these experiments represents an area of active research - until we have gathered many results from people like you
column2: we can't conclude anything about what volunteers' results mean. Furthermore
column3: these kinds of results are only meaningful at the group level - that is
column4: they may reflect patterns that apply on average and not necessarily to any one person. For example
column5: let's say we decided to do a study examining gender and hair length. We might find that
column7: women have longer hair than men. However
column8: having long hair doesn't make you female and being female doesn't give you long hair. In other words
column9: females have longer hair on average
column10: but this logic cannot be applied to individuals.

column1: If you are surprised by your results on any of these tests
column2: you shouldn't be concerned. There are many reasons why scores on this task might differ. For instance
column3: differences in computer systems or distractions while doing the task can affect results. This task was not designed to specifically assess you
column4: and the scores can vary widely among the people who complete it.

column1: If you have any questions about these or any of your results
